Award.AbstractNarration:
The Institute for Advanced Study/Park City Mathematics Institute

(PCMI) is a 3-week-long summer mathematics institute, which began over 20 years ago as an NSF-funded Regional Geometry Institute. Each PCMI summer program is organized around a single topic of contemporary mathematical research, which varies from year to year. PCMI's summer programs are of very high quality and are unique in integrating undergraduate mathematics studies, graduate mathematics studies and mathematics research activities through coordinated, concurrent programs. PCMI also has parallel programs for undergraduate faculty and secondary school teachers, whose participants benefit from their proximity to students and researchers. The undergraduate faculty participants develop educational materials related to the research topic for inclusion in undergraduate courses.


PCMI has many positive and profound effects on the mathematics community. The undergraduate and graduate summer programs, through the quality of their lecture series and their close relation with a cutting-edge research topic, create excitement among the students and are effective at recruiting students into the mathematics discipline. The unique integration of students, educators and researchers results in many positive interactions, which include collaborations between students and researchers. To ensure that PCMI's lecture series have enduring impact, the graduate student summer school lectures are published by the American Mathematical Society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IAS/PCMI program, now in its 25th year, is a summer institute uniquely aimed toward the entire mathematical community, from senior researchers, though graduate and undergraduate students, undergraduate faculty, mentors for underrepresented cohorts of students, extending all the way to K-12 teachers. All but this last component are NSF-funded. Each year the mathematical focus is different: a group of three or four organizers who are specialists in a given area of mathematics help shape the research and graduate components of the program. The fields represented during this grant’s period were: Image Processing, Moduli spaces of Riemann surfaces, Geometric group theory, Geometric analysis, and Mathematics and Materials. The scientific level of the meetings are very high: the workshop is designed for the dissemination of recent work in the area and to provide a forum for high-level interaction, and the lecturers and topics for the graduate mini-courses are carefully chosen to help train a new generation of students and young researchers in that field. The graduate lectures are later published as a monograph by the AMS; these volumes are widely used as entry points into research in each of these fields.

 

The intellectual merit of the program is very high: around 160 top-level mathematicians and students, including researchers and students from a broad spectrum of institutions, are brought together for this intensive program. The mathematical themes are chosen to be timely and very active ones in mathematics or at the intersection of mathematics with other disciplines. The interactions developed and nurtured at PCMI consistently foster an intensity and thus lead to important mathematical progress in these fields. 

 

The PCMI program has significant broader impact as well. It includes a superior training program in important mathematical disciplines, and serves as a major pipeline for students and young researchers. It provides extensive opportunities for these participants to interact and build networks with one another as well as with senior researchers in the field.

 

Other NSF-funded components of PCMI include a set of courses and activities aimed at undergraduate students, another aimed at the professional development of faculty at predominantly undergraduate institutions, and a workshop for college faculty focusing on helping them develop ways to encourage and increase the participation of students from underrepresented groups in mathematics and other STEM fields. There is another non-NSF funded component to PCMI which is a large K-12 teacher development program; over 60 teachers each year gather for a series of courses focused on mathematical content, which not only increase their knowledge of and passion for the subject but which also help them develop new curricula and ways to spread what they learn at PCMI to other teachers in their home schools and districts. Perhaps the most novel aspect of PCMI, and a clear indication of broader impact, is the way that these various groups from the entire spectrum of the mathematical community live and work together for the three-week program. A number of activities of the program are cross-disciplinary and aimed at finding ways to help people from these various groups interact and gain respect for the successes and challenges in each of the other groups, as well as to gain a sense of the breadth of the entire mathematical community.
